media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 5th January 2025
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00:00 - Music before the service
06:45 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
07:00 - Welcome and Lighting of peace candle (by Duty Elder)
08:10 - Call to worship
09:20 - 12:20 - HYMN Worship the Lord
12:33 - 14:46 - Prayer of adoration and confession
14:52 - 23:38 - Introduction for all ages: ‘12 th Day of Christmas and…’
23:53 - 25:53 - HYMN Born in the night Junior Church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing – the Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at back of church.
Introduction to the readings 26:51 - 28:10 - Reading: John 1. 10 – 18 NIVUK read by Linda
28:16 - Reading Psalm 117 (Lectern side / keyboard side) L Praise the Lord, all nations everywhere. K Praise God, all the peoples of the earth. L For God loves us very dearly, K and God’s truth endures. ALL PRAISE THE LORD. K Praise the Lord, all nations everywhere. L Praise God, all the peoples of the earth. K For God loves us very dearly, L and God’s truth endures. ALL PRAISE THE LORD.
29:43 - 31:17 - Reading: Ephesians 1.3-14 NIVUK read by Linda
31:50 - 33:51 - HYMN Peace perfect peace
34:16 - 46:53 - Short Address
47:29 - 50:55 - Prayers of intercessions
51:43 - 53:53 - HYMN Christ is coming, TUNE: RS 184 DIX Christ is coming, Christ has come, let the world prepare a room. God says: Light! and makes our day: fear and chaos lose their say. In our darkness shines our Sun; God has made a date with man.
Christ has come, will come again, parable of God and Man. Lord of all our unborn days, world renewing turn of phrase, Word in season for all time, godly reason, godly rhyme.
Let the earth make time and room for the Man who is to come. He, the centre of our feast, makes himself of all the least. Stones and voices all proclaim: There is bread in Bethlehem! Fred Kaan © 1975 Hope Publishing Company CCLL 36750
53:57 - Thanksgiving Prayer and Lord’s Prayer Distribution of bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice)
01:02:08 - Final prayer
01:04:36 - 01:08:10 - HYMN Lord for the years
01:08:11 - 01:08:39 - Blessing
01:09:01 - 01:11:34 - Music after the service
#advent #AdventCandle #AdventRing #StickMan #JuliaDonaldson #ImStickManThatsMe

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 29th December 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00:00 - Music before the service
05:10 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
05:13 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
06:35 - Call to Worship (Psalm 148. 1 – 5)
07:33 - 12:29 - Hymn Of the Fathers love begotten
12:33 - 15:54 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
16:20 - 16:59 - Reading: 1 Samuel 2. 18 -20 and 26 18 But Samuel was ministering before the Lord – a boy wearing a linen ephod. 19 Each year his mother made him a little robe and took it to him when she went up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice. 20 Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife, saying, ‘May the Lord give you children by this woman to take the place of the one she prayed for and gave to the Lord.’ Then they would go home. 26 And the boy Samuel continued to grow in stature and in favour with the Lord and with people.
17:07 - 21:16 - Introduction to the service (All age talk)
21:28 - 23:49 - Hymn Unto us a boy is born
24:12 - 25:36 - Reading: Luke 2. 41 – 52 41 Every year Jesus’ parents went to Jerusalem for the Festival of the Passover. 42 When he was twelve years old, they went up to the festival, according to the custom. 43 After the festival was over, while his parents were returning home, the boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem, but they were unaware of it. 44 Thinking he was in their company, they travelled on for a day. Then they began looking for him among their relatives and friends. 45 When they did not find him, they went back to Jerusalem to look for him. 46 After three days they found him in the temple courts, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions. 47 Everyone who heard him was amazed at his understanding and his answers. 48 When his parents saw him, they were astonished. His mother said to him, ‘Son, why have you treated us like this? Your father and I have been anxiously searching for you.’ 49 ‘Why were you searching for me?’ he asked. ‘Didn’t you know I had to be in my Father’s house?’[a] 50 But they did not understand what he was saying to them. 51 Then he went down to Nazareth with them and was obedient to them. But his mother treasured all these things in her heart. 52 And Jesus grew in wisdom and stature, and in favour with God and man.
26:01 - 28:58 - Hymn Take my life and let it be
29:28 - 38:06 - Address
38:30 - 40:21 - Hymn 146 Away in a manger
40:25 - 44:20 - Prayers of intercession
44:37 - 49:21 - Hymn In the bleak mid winter
49:21 - 49:43 - Blessing
50:04 - 52:12 - Music after the service
#advent #AdventCandle #AdventRing

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Christmas Day, 25th December 2024
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Music and photos before the service
06:05 - 08:33 - Carol to prepare for worship R&S 153 On Christmas night
08:38 - Welcome and introduction (including lighting of peace candle)
10:18 - Call to worship Into this space, into our prayers, Jesus, we welcome you. Into our sadnesses, into our celebrations, Jesus, we welcome you. Into our homes, into our families, Jesus, we welcome you. Into our lives, into our hearts, Jesus, we welcome you. We offer our worship, we offer our thanks For you are ‘God with us’ now and for ever. Amen.
11:04 - HYMN R&S 160 O come all ye faithful (omit verses 3 and 4)
14:37 - Lighting the Advent Candles and opening prayer Lord Jesus, be with us in all our celebrations today. Shine your light into our lives. Bring your love, hope and peace to our broken world, that all creation may learn the song of the angels: Glory to God in the highest and peace on earth. Amen.
18:09 - SONG Tune: Frère Jacques Christ our Lord: Christ our Lord, light our lives light our lives. We’ll be lights to others: we’ll be lights to others. Light our lives: light our lives.
19:22 - 25:40 - Introduction: ‘simply the best!’
25:51 - 26:48 - Reading: Luke 2. 1 – 7 read by Julia Sparks
27:01 - 28:41 - HYMN R&S 149 Infant lowly, infant holy
29:06 - 30:51 - Reading: Luke 2. 8 – 20 read by Stephen Burton
31:02 - 33:46 - Reflection: ‘The child in a manger’
33:55 - 36:06 - HYMN R&S 166 Come and join the celebration
36:23 - 41:58 - Prayers for those in need with the response God with us, be with them. Lord’s Prayer
42:59 - 47:14 - HYMN R&S 157 See, in yonder manger low
47:15 - 47:44 - Blessing
47:57 - 49:42 - Music after the service
#advent #AdventCandle #AdventRing

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Carols with Candlelight - Sunday, 15th December 2024 4pm
media:group.media:description:
Welcome to this special service. We hope you enjoy the worship and are able to stay for refreshments afterwards.
07:23 - Welcome
08:45 - Call to worship led by the minister, Terry Hinks Jesus said ‘I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will not walk in darkness but will have the light of life.’ In the tender mercy of our God, the dawn from on high has broken upon us, to give light to those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death, and to guide our feet into the way of peace.
09:42 - 14:24 - Carol: O come all ye faithful
14:32 - Lighting of the Advent Candles and Opening Prayer
17:49 - 20:59 - Carol: Silent night
21:16 - 22:29 - 1st Bible Reading: Isaiah 52. 7 – 10 Harri
23:03 - 24:57 - Reading: ‘Christmas Bells’ Arthur
25:02 - 28:35 - Carol: It came upon a midnight clear
28:42 - 29:53 - 2nd Bible Reading: Luke 2: 1–7 Rosemary
30:36 - 33:11 - Carol: O sad and troubled Bethlehem [on screen - tune R&S 145]
33:24 - A Prayer for Peace
35:43 - 37:13 - 3rd Bible Reading: Luke 2: 8 – 20 Richard
Carol: See him lying on a bed of straw (Band) [on screen or R&S 151]
40:26 - 41:16 - Reading: ‘A work in progress’ Jeanny
41:24 - Songs: Meekness and majesty (vs 1 and 3) 43:37 - Longing for light (vs 1 and 2)
45:22 - 47:13 - 4th Bible Reading: Matthew 2: 1 – 12 Samuel
47:26 - Introducing our charity: Embrace the Middle East - slides and video
52:24 - 53:08 - Reading: ‘What God sent’ Sheila
53:17 - 54:50 - Carol Love came down at Christmas
54:57 - 57:00 - 5th Bible Reading: John 1: 1 – 14 Terry
57:06 - 01:01:00 - Prayers for the world God loves and the Lord’s Prayer All: Our Father, who art in heaven, hallowed be thy name; thy kingdom come; thy will be done; on earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread. And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive those who trespass against us. And lead us not into temptation; but deliver us from evil. For thine is the kingdom, the power, and the glory, for ever and ever. Amen.
01:02:27 - Carol: Hark! the herald angels sing [on screen or R&S 159]
01:05:35 - 01:06:01 - Minister: Blessing All say: Amen.
01:06:21 - 01:09:28 - Organ Voluntary
Retiring Collection in aid of Embrace the Middle East (working with Christian partners to respond to the desperate need the Middle East caught up in warfare and tackle long-term poverty and injustice) For more information see the website: https://embraceme.org/
#advent #AdventCandle #AdventRing

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 15th December 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00:00 - Music before the service
05:32 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
05:40 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
07:35 - Call to worship
08:04 - 11:35 - Hymn Long ago prophets knew Tune: R & S 274 Theodoric
11:40 - 14:26 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
14:32 - 18:25 - Talk for all ages: ‘making clean’
16:54 - 18:25 - Reading Luke 3.15-16 (The Message) The interest of the people by now was building. They were all beginning to wonder, “Could this John be the Messiah?” But John intervened: “I’m baptizing you here in the river. The main character in this drama, to whom I’m a mere stagehand, will ignite the kingdom life, a fire, the Holy Spirit within you, changing you from the inside out. He’s going to clean house—make a clean sweep of your lives.
18:29 - Lighting of the Advent Candles and prayer
Today we light 3 candles, the 1 st to remember for the great hope God has given us, the 2 nd to give thanks for the Bible and the prophets. And now the 3 rd candle to give thanks for John the Baptist, who prepared the way for Jesus. God of hope, come to us again this Advent. Prepare us in heart and mind to welcome your light and walk in your way. Amen
19:58 - 22:49 - Hymn - R&S 141 Make way, make way
Junior Church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing – the Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at the back of church.
Introduction to Bible readings
23:29 - 25:15 - Readings: Zephaniah 3.14-20 read by Abigail Lokko
25:34 - 26:23 - Isaiah 12.2 – 6 read by Alan Yates and congregation Surely God is my salvation; I will trust and not be afraid. The Lord, the Lord himself, is my strength and my defence; he has become my salvation.’ 3 With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation. ‘Give praise to the Lord, proclaim his name; make known among the nations what he has done, and proclaim that his name is exalted. 5 Sing to the Lord, for he has done glorious things; let this be known to all the world. 6 Shout aloud and sing for joy, people of Zion, for great is the Holy One of Israel among you.
26:26 - 27:17 - Reading: Philippians 4.4-7 read by Alan Yates
27:41 - Hymn R&S 286 Rejoice in the Lord (sung as a round)
29:55 - 40:45 - Address followed by time of quiet reflection
40:48 - HYMN Don’t be afraid, my love is stronger My love is stronger than your fear. Don’t be afraid, my love is stronger And I have promised, promised to be always near.
43:05 - 50:12 - Prayers of thanksgiving and intercession
50:41 - 52:42 - Hymn - R&S 150 Child in the manger
52:43 - 53:10 - Blessing
53:26 - 56:07 - Music after the service
#advent #AdventCandle #AdventRing

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 1st December 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship and remembrance from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00:00 - Music before the service
05:50 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
05:58 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
08:00 - 08:40 - Call to worship Minister: In our watching and waiting: All: Come, Lord Jesus. Minister: In our hopes and fears: All: Come, Lord Jesus. Minister: In our stillness and worship: All: Come, Lord Jesus. Minister: Come, Lord Jesus, bless and surprise us, as we look forward to the celebration of your birth and the final victory of your kingdom.
09:22 - 11:56 - Hymn - Tell out my soul 740
12:00 - Opening Prayers
14:28 - 22:10 - Introduction: ‘getting ready’
22:12 - Lighting first candle on Advent crown Minister: We light our first candle, as a sign of our hope that peace and justice will come to our world: All: God of hope, come to us again this Advent. May your hope live within us, burning as a light in our lives. Amen.
23:49 - 26:12 - Hymn - Like a candle flame
27:06 - 28:33 - Readings: Jeremiah 33. 14 – 16 read by Lesley Psalm 25. 1 – 5 read by Lesley and congregation Reader: In you, Lord my God, I put my trust. All: I trust in you; do not let me be put to shame, nor let my enemies triumph over me. Reader: No one who hopes in you will ever be put to shame, but shame will come on those who are treacherous without cause. All: Show me your ways, Lord, teach me your paths. Reader: Guide me in your truth and teach me, All: for you are God my Saviour, and my hope is in you all day long. Amen.
28:49 - 30:50 - Reading Luke 21.25 – 36 read by Ian
31:41 - 34:18 - Hymn - O come O come Emmanuel (vs 1,2 and 6)
34:53 - 47:56 - Short Address
48:05 - 53:23 - Prayers of intercession Minister: Lord, your kingdom come All: your will be done.
53:30 - Offering of bread and wine and Offering Prayer We invite you to share in the bread and wine (grape juice) at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ.
54:48 - Hymn - Be known to us in breaking bread
56:17 - Thanksgiving Prayer and Lord’s Prayer
59:07 - Distribution of bread and wine
01:05:02 - Closing Prayer
01:07:49 - 01:10:10 - Hymn - Joy to the world R&S135
01:10:12 - 01:10:42 - Blessing
01:11:08 - 01:14:35 - Music after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 10th November 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship and remembrance from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00:00 - Music before the service Photos before the service are mostly from Ypers, Belgium and the surrounding area
05:12 - Entry of the bbile
05:27 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
07:02 - Call to worship - Psalm 62
08:56 - 12:43 - Hymn - O worship the King
12:48 - Opening Prayers of adoration and confession The Lord’s Prayer (traditional words)
16:53 - 17:50 - Reading: Jonah 3. 1 – 5, 10 read by Sarah
18:01 - 23:27 - Introduction for all ages (all age talk) Dog walking, smells Tree surgery, ropes, climbing Notes and messages Be prepared to bravely answer the call from God
23:37 - Hymn - Dear Lord and Father of mankind
Junior Church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing – the Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at back of church.
28:39 - Act of remembrance including the Two Minute Silence They shall grow not old as those who are left to grow old: Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. At the going down of the sun and in the morning, we will remember them. WE WILL REMEMBER THEM
Last post Silence Reveille
When you go home, tell them of us and say, for your tomorrow we gave our today.
33:35 - Hymn - O God our help in ages past
37:20 - 38:39 - Reading: Mark 1. 14 – 20 read by Rosemary
39:34 - 47:11 - Address "At the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month, the guns fell silent" - The Silence of Remembrance: Emphasising the power of silence in remembrance, particularly the two-minute silence observed on Remembrance Day. - The Cost of War: The immense human cost of war, including the physical, emotional, and spiritual sacrifices made by soldiers and civilians. - The Hope of Resurrection: Despite the darkness and despair of war, a message of hope, drawing parallels to the Christian belief in resurrection and the triumph of life over death. - The Call to Follow: Connecting the sacrifices of soldiers to the call of discipleship, urging listeners to follow Jesus' example of selfless love and service. - The Eucharistic Silence: Exploring the significance of the silent moment during the Eucharistic consecration, likening it to the silence of Holy Saturday. - The Power of Sacrifice: both in the context of war and in the Christian faith. - The Weight of Remembrance: to honor the fallen and to strive for a more peaceful future. - The Mystery of Suffering: and the difficulty of understanding why such tragedies occur. - The Importance of Community both in supporting one another and in working towards a more just and compassionate world. - The Transformative power of love, which can overcome even the darkest of times.
47:30 - 50:30 - Hymn - All people that on earth do dwell
50:34 - 53:41 - Prayers of intercession
53:57 - Hymn - God is love let heaven adore him
57:38 - 58:08 - Blessing
58:30 - 01:03:44 - Music after the service
#remember #Remembrance #poppies #Tynecote #ruepettlion #SundayInspiration #EverySunday #WeWillRememerThem #RemembranceSunday #ArmisticeDay #WW1 #LestWeForget #SilentTribute #Peace #Hope #Sacrifice #ChristianReflection #ChurchSermon #SpiritualInsights #FaithAndHope #WarMemorial #PoppyAppeal #RememberTheFallen

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 3rd November 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00:00 - Music before the service
05:56 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
06:12 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
08:30 - Call to worship (from Psalm 146.1, 2, 5 and 6) Praise the Lord, my soul. I will praise the Lord, all my life; I will sing praise to my God as long as I live. Blessed are those whose help is the God of Jacob, whose hope is in the Lord their God. The Lord is the Maker of heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them: God remains faithful for ever.
09:26 - 12:35 - Hymn - For all the saints R&S 658
12:40 - 14:51 - Opening Prayer of adoration and confession
14:58 - 33:38 - Introduction: ‘Who gets your vote?’
33:47 - 34:52 - Reading: Hebrews 11. 1 – 3 NIVUK (minister and all)
To have faith is to be sure of the things we hope for, to be certain of the things we cannot see. It was by their faith that people of ancient times won God's approval. It is by faith that we understand that the universe was created by God's word, so that what can be seen was made out of what cannot be seen. Thanks be to the God who gives life and hope and faith. Amen.
35:11 - 36:38 - Hymn - In my life Lord be glorified R&S 375
Junior Church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing – the Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at back of church. Introducing the readings
38:39 - 39:41 - Reading: Isaiah 25. 6 – 9 NIVUK read by Kitty Bird
40:00 - 40:33 - Psalm 117 Praise the Lord, all nations! Praise God, all peoples! God’s love for us is strong, and God’s faithfulness is eternal. Praise the Lord! Praise the Lord! Amen.
40:54 - 43:47 - Reading: Hebrews 11. 32 – 12.3 NIVUK read by Harri Bello
44:12 - 46:41 - Song - He is Lord R&S 264
47:06 - 57:31 - Short Address
57:32 - 59:59 - Prayers of intercession
01:00:15 - 01:02:50 - Hymn - I come with joy to meet my Lord R&S 447

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 6th October 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:04 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
00:11 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
02:19 - Introduction and Call to worship This the day that the Lord has made: Let us rejoice and be glad in it. It is good to give thanks to the Lord: For God’s love endures for ever.
03:05 - Hymn - Lord Jesus Christ
06:09 - 08:24 - Opening Prayers of adoration and confession God our Father, we have sinned against you and against one another, in thought, word and deed; we have not loved you with all our heart; we have not loved our neighbour as ourselves. But you have kept faith with us. Have mercy on us, forgive us our sins, and restore us to newness of life; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen. Assurance of forgiveness Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners. To all who turn to him he says: ‘Your sins are forgiven.’ He also says: ‘Follow me.’ Thanks be to God. Amen.
08:30 - 18:20 - Introduction for all ages: ‘barriers overcome’ Highlighting various "No Entry" signs as symbols of exclusion. The importance of accessibility in churches for people with disabilities Sight Loss Sunday and the need for churches to be inclusive of those with visual impairments. Hidden disabilities like hearing loss and the importance of accommodations like loop systems. Sign language is mentioned as a tool for inclusion. The concept of "walls" is explored, both physical and mental barriers that separate people. The biblical story of Jesus welcoming children is used as an example of breaking down barriers. The disciples' initial rejection of children is contrasted with Jesus' inclusive approach. The sermon concludes with Jesus rebuking the disciples and stating that the kingdom of God belongs to those like children.
#Inclusion #BreakingBarriers #Accessibility #ChurchForAll #SightLossSunday #HiddenDisabilities #SignLanguage #NoEntry #WelcomingChurch #JesusAndChildren #KingdomOfGod #Equality #Acceptance #OvercomingPrejudice #DivineLove
18:38 - 19:18 - Reading: Mark 10. 13 – 16 read by Lesley
19:46 - 21:50 - Hymn - As we are gathered Jesus is here
22:22 - 23:33 - Reading: Psalm 8 read by Ian
23:44 - 25:59 - Hebrews 1.1 – 4 and 2.5 – 12 read by Lesley
26:49 - Hymn - Be still for the presence of our Lord
29:59 - 43:32 - Short Address Reflecting on what it means to be human from a faith perspective. Psalm 8, which contrasts human insignificance with God's mindfulness of humanity. The destructive aspects of human behavior, including environmental damage and war. Jesus' welcome of children is highlighted as a radical act in its historical context. The praise of children is presented as a powerful force against evil. The psalm speaks of humanity being crowned with glory and honor by God. Jesus is described as the truest human, who has shared in human suffering. The creation of a new human family through Jesus' grace is emphasized. Being human involves recognizing our insignificance while also embracing our God-given dignity.
This sermon explores the complex nature of humanity through a Christian lens, drawing on Psalm 8 and the teachings of Jesus. It grapples with the paradox of human insignificance in the face of the universe's vastness, while also affirming the unique value and responsibility God places on humanity. The speaker addresses both the destructive capacities of humans and their potential for compassion and praise. Jesus is presented as the model of true humanity, offering a path to a new family united by divine grace. The sermon concludes by defining being human as a balance between humility before God and the honor of being part of God's creation, with the communion table serving as a symbol of this united humanity.
43:47 - 46:24 - Prayers of intercession
46:41 - Hymn - The love of God
50:17 - Communion: all invited to share in the bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice) to remember Jesus.
Prayer of thanksgiving The Lord’s Prayer (traditional words)
53:09 - Distribution of communion
59:17 - Closing Prayer
01:00:23 - HYMN Now let us from this table rise
01:02:50 - 01:03:15 - Closing blessing
01:04:00 - 01:06:50 - Music after the service
#SundayInspiration #EverySunday

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 29th September 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
The service is focused on the theme of stewardship, emphasizing our responsibility to care for the planet and its inhabitants. It explores the biblical creation story and its implications for human responsibility to care for the Earth. The service acknowledges the significant environmental challenges facing our planet, such as climate change and biodiversity loss. It connects faith to stewardship, emphasizing that caring for the Earth is a Christian duty. The service encourages individuals to take action in their daily lives to reduce their environmental impact, such as recycling, conserving energy, and eating sustainably. It emphasizes the importance of collective action to address environmental challenges, including advocating for policies and practices that protect the planet. The service highlights the role of the church in promoting sustainability and concludes with a message of hope and encouragement.
Our Focus on Stewardship: We're focusing on stewardship, emphasizing our responsibility to care for the planet and its inhabitants. Creation and Our Responsibility: We're exploring the biblical creation story and its implications for our human responsibility to care for the Earth. Environmental Challenges: We're acknowledging the significant environmental challenges facing our planet, such as climate change and biodiversity loss. Faith and Stewardship: We're connecting faith to stewardship, emphasizing that caring for the Earth is a Christian duty. Individual Actions: We're encouraging individuals to take action in their daily lives to reduce their environmental impact, such as recycling, conserving energy, and eating sustainably. Community Action: We're emphasizing the importance of collective action to address environmental challenges, including advocating for policies and practices that protect the planet. Our Church's Role: We're highlighting our church's role in promoting environmental stewardship, including reducing our own carbon footprint and advocating for climate justice. Personal Reflection: We're inviting participants to reflect on their own relationship with nature and how they can live more sustainably. Hope and Action: We're concluding with a message of hope and encouragement, emphasizing that individual and collective actions can make a difference in protecting the planet.
00:00:00 - Music before the service
05:16 - Entry of the bible, welcome and lighting of the peace candle
07:07 - Welcome and call to worship
08:12 - 10:04 - Hymn - Morning has broken 45
10:15 - Intro to theme, what we will be thinking about/ policy from URC on climate change
12:24 - 16:11 - Creation readings
16:26 - 20:14 - Talk - God created us, stewardship, and our beliefs
20:15 - Break into table groups, discuss bible readings about the environment No verbal feedback but people may wish to write reflections on paper/area to share
49:31 - 52:45 - Hymn - Think of a world without any flowers-123
53:05 - 54:28 - Short prayer and Lord’s prayer
54:35 - What do we do at the moment to care for the world? Give ideas Watch presentation then discuss on tables Any new ideas?
01:12:24 - 01:15:24 - Hymn - All creatures of our God and king
01:15:37 -01:18:28 - Prayer
01:18:33 - What is stewardship of the planet What one more thing could you do? - ? Write down your commitment to that? All the little actions add up…
01:27:42 - 01:30:10 - Hymn -You shall go out with joy-415
01:30:18 - 01:30:55 - Closing blessing
01:31:17 - 01:35:05 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 8th September 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
02:12 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
02:23 - Welcome and Lighting of peace candle (by Duty Elder)
04:21 - Call to worship We gather today in the presence of our compassionate God, who heals and restores. Let us open our hearts to his love and grace. May our worship be a source of hope and encouragement, as we stand in solidarity with our brothers and sisters around the world.
04:49 - 07:39 - Hymn R&S 474 Brother, sister let me serve you
07:46 - Opening Prayers and The Lord’s Prayer
11:16 - 16:45 - Introduction for all ages: Let’s learn about Nepal
17:12 - 18:01 - Reading: Matthew 8. 1-4 - Jesus heals a man with leprosy read by David Bishop: When Jesus came down from the mountainside, large crowds followed him. A man with leprosy came and knelt beside him and said, ‘Lord, if you are willing, you can make me clean. Jesus reached out his hand and touched the man. ‘I am willing’, he said. ’Be clean!’ Immediately he was cleansed of his leprosy. Then Jesus said to him, See that you don’t tell anyone. But go, show yourself to the priest and offer the gift Moses commanded, as a testimony to them.
18:19 - 21:18 - Hymn R&S 549 One more step along the way I go
Junior church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing - The Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at the back of the church.
21:49 - 22:48 - Reading: Luke 17. 11-19 Jesus heals ten men with leprosy read by Valerie Bishop: Now on his way to Jerusalem, Jesus travelled along the border between Samaria and Galilee. As he was going into a village, ten men who had leprosy met him. They stood at a distance and called out in a loud voice, ‘Jesus, Master, have pity on us!. When he saw them, he said ‘Go, show yourself to the priests.’ And as they went they were cleansed. One of them, when he saw he was healed, came back in a loud voice. He threw himself at Jesus feet and thanked him – and he was a Samaritan. Jesus asked, ‘Where not all ten men cleansed? Where are the other nine? Has no one returned to give praise to God except this foreigner? Then he said to him, ‘Rise and go; your faith has made you well.
23:07 - 27:06 - Hymn R&S 92 Amazing Grace
27:32 - 48:48 - Talk by Dawn Macaulay and video followed by a time of quiet reflection
50:01 - 53:38 - Hymn R&S 274 God is love
53:49 - 58:04 - Prayers of Intercession for the World Offering prayer: Gracious God, you have blessed us beyond our deserving. You have given us more than we could ever have dared ask for, loving us with a love that refuses to count the cost, showering us with good things too many to number. Gracious God, for your generous and wonderful gifts we praise you, we give our offering as a token of our thanksgiving, in the name of Christ. Amen
59:04 - 01:03:05 - Hymn R&S 96 Great is thy faithfulness
01:03:09 - 01:03:25 - Closing blessing
01:03:57 - 01:06:28 - Music after the service
